verses.text: Afterward, Moses and Aaron went and said to Pharaoh, "This is what Yahweh, the God of Israel, says: 'Let My people go, so they may hold a festival to Me in the wilderness.'"
verses.comment: Kept the divine name as 'Yahweh' reflecting the Hebrew YHWH; 'Festival' for 'feast'.

verses.text: But Pharaoh said, "Who is Yahweh, that I should obey His voice and let Israel go? I do not know Yahweh, and I will not let Israel go."
verses.comment: Direct and literal translation; the challenge to God's authority is preserved.

verses.text: Then they said, "The God of the Hebrews has met with us. Please let us go on a three-day journey into the wilderness, so we may sacrifice to Yahweh our God, or else He may strike us with plague or with the sword."
verses.comment: 'Sacrifice' preserved as in Hebrew; 'plague' and 'sword' as literal translation.

verses.text: But the king of Egypt said to them, "Moses and Aaron, why do you take the people away from their work? Go back to your labor."
verses.comment: Direct, word-for-word request; labor/work for 'burdens'.

verses.text: And Pharaoh said, "Look, the people of the land are now many, and you are making them rest from their labor!"
verses.comment: Maintains the sense of 'rest' (Hebrew: shabath), often translated 'stop working'.

verses.text: That same day Pharaoh commanded the overseers of the people and their foremen,
verses.comment: Overseers and foremen are literal from Hebrew 'shoterim' and 'nogesim'.

verses.text: "You must no longer give straw to the people to make bricks as before. Let them go and gather straw for themselves."
verses.comment: Straw and bricks per literal; maintain original command.

verses.text: "But you shall require of them the same number of bricks as they made before; do not reduce it, for they are idle. Therefore they cry out, 'Let us go and sacrifice to our God.'"
verses.comment: Maintains accusation of 'idleness'.

verses.text: "Let heavier work be laid on the men, so that they may labor and pay no attention to lying words."
verses.comment: Accusation of 'lying words' kept literal.

verses.text: And the overseers of the people and their foremen went out and said to the people, "Thus says Pharaoh, 'I will not give you straw.'"
verses.comment: 'Thus says Pharaoh' echoes prophetic formula reversed.

verses.text: "Go, get straw for yourselves wherever you can find it, but none of your work will be reduced."
verses.comment: Direct instruction; 'none of your work will be reduced' for clarity.

verses.text: So the people scattered throughout all the land of Egypt to gather stubble for straw.
verses.comment: 'Stubble' accurately reflects leftover stalks.

verses.text: The overseers kept pressing them, saying, "Finish your work, your daily quota, as when you had straw."
verses.comment: Quota/number is literal for 'tasks'.

verses.text: And the foremen of the Israelites, whom Pharaoh's overseers had appointed, were beaten, and were asked, "Why have you not fulfilled your quota of bricks yesterday and today, as before?"
verses.comment: Explicit about beating; time marker 'yesterday and today' added for accuracy.

verses.text: Then the foremen of the Israelites came and cried out to Pharaoh, "Why do you treat your servants this way?"
verses.comment: Literal plea to Pharaoh.

verses.text: "No straw is given to your servants, yet they say to us, 'Make bricks!' And your servants are beaten, but the fault is with your own people."
verses.comment: Keeps the complaint structure.

verses.text: But he said, "You are idle, you are idle! That is why you say, 'Let us go and sacrifice to Yahweh.'"
verses.comment: Dual repetition of 'idle' preserved.

verses.text: "Go now and work; for no straw will be given to you, but you must still deliver the same quota of bricks."
verses.comment: Maintains structure of command.

verses.text: The foremen of the Israelites saw that they were in trouble when they were told, "You must not reduce your daily quota of bricks."
verses.comment: 'Trouble' for 'evil' to clarify context.

verses.text: When they came out from Pharaoh, they met Moses and Aaron, who were waiting for them.
verses.comment: Scene change and meeting clarified.

verses.text: And they said to them, "May Yahweh look upon you and judge, because you have made us stink in the eyes of Pharaoh and in the eyes of his servants, and have put a sword in their hand to kill us."
verses.comment: 'Made us stink' is literal Hebrew idiom, preserved; 'kill us' clarifies the threat.

verses.text: Then Moses turned to Yahweh and said, "Lord, why have You brought trouble on this people? Why did You send me?"
verses.comment: 'Trouble' for 'evil' to reflect context; maintains Mosesâ€™ lament.

verses.text: "For since I came to Pharaoh to speak in Your name, he has done evil to this people, and You have not delivered Your people at all."
verses.comment: Phrase 'at all' intensifies the complaint, as in Hebrew; 'evil' for original meaning.
